item.title: [Hyperion] Regions
item.dc:creator: @relexlawl relexlawl
item.description:
@relexlawl wrote:

Okay then just add a boolean in the game object file like:

private boolean cached;

public boolean isCached() {
return cached;
}

public void setCachedState(boolean cached) {
this.cached = cached;
}

then on the start-up method for loading cache objects (assuming you have the objects loading there) you would make the isCached boolean true and when you need to update regions you would just add the check && !object.isCached() (also remember to set the isCached boolean to false for doors when they are in the state they aren’t set to default, so doors that are closed by default and is opened should have the isCached boolean set to false, you would just put this in the openDoor method door.setCachedState(!door.isCached()))

item.title: [Hyperion] Regions
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

After looking through the source code, it looks like you can accomplish this by modifying the addToRegion() method in the Player class, or the addPlayer method in the Region class, so that when the player is entering a new Region, all of the new GameObjects are sent to the player. Now, I’m not sure exactly how to do that, as the RSWiki doesn’t seem to have any documentation on that (or those) specific packets that I could see, and it’s not already in the Hyperion framework. You should be able to steal if out of a wL source, and modify like that though.

An example of the code would be something like

public void addToRegion(Region region) {
    region.addPlayer(this);
    for (GameObject obj : region.getObjects()) {
        ActionSender.sendObject(this, obj.getX(), obj.getY(), etc);
    }
}
